title-group.article-title: Inequality and Two Decades of British Tax and Benefit Reforms

abstract.p: Microsimulation methods are used to identify the contribution of tax and benefit reforms to the significant growth in UK income inequality since 1979. The total effect turns out to depend crucially on the counterfactual against which the reforms are assessed: compared with the alternative of pure price-indexation, the total effect of reform is small; by contrast, compared with a counterfactual in which benefits rose in line with national income (historically the case before 1979), the effect is substantial — approximately half the total rise in income inequality is explained. The impact of reforms on inequality has varied significantly over time: income tax cuts in the late 1970s and late 1980s increased inequality; direct tax rises in the early 1980s and 1990s, together with increases in means-tested benefits in the late 1990s, reduced it. The robustness of the results to sampling variation and to the measure of inequality used is also investigated.

The Gini coefficient is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 represents total income equality (everyone in the economy has the same income) and 1 represents total inequality (all income is owned by just one person). Thus, the higher the value of the Gini coefficient, the higher is inequality.

We estimate that the Fowler reforms reduced the Gini coefficient by 0.1 percentage points. For more on these reforms, see Dilnot and Webb (1988). Progressive features included an increase in means-tested benefits for families with children, although these were at least partially offset by other regressive changes, such as the introduction of the Social Fund, a cash-limited pool of money available as loans to those in need rather than the payments for exceptional need system that operated under the supplementary benefit system which was abolished as part of the reforms.

As we indicated in Section ID, we are not able to model all the changes to non-means-tested benefits. Important reforms that we will not have captured with accuracy (owing to data paucity) include the increased work conditionality for unemployment benefit, reductions in the value of state earnings-related pensions and the stricter medical conditionality of incapacity benefit compared with the invalidity benefit it replaced.

From 1993 onwards, the data are on a financial-year basis, so the April 1996 reforms, for example, are modelled on the 1995-96 data-set. Before 1993, the data are on a calendar-year basis, so data from the calendar year before the April in question are used — for example, the April 1988 reforms are modelled on 1987 data.

When run on 1997-98 data, we saw that the overall effect of the full 22 years of reform was to reduce inequality relative to the counterfactual 'no change' by 0.1 percentage points. When run on 1979 data throughout, the effect is to reduce inequality by 0.8 percentage points; on 1986 data, the effect is a reduction of 0.5 percentage points; and when run on 1999-2000 Family Resources Survey data — which have been more rigorously checked for consistency than the 1999-2000 FES data — we see an increase in inequality of 0.6 percentage points. These are all small changes which follow the intuition suggested earlier: given the underlying increase in the dispersion of income since 1979, the effect of the reforms to the tax and benefit system is to increase inequality less the earlier the data we use.

However, it is important to note that in the early 1980s, the tax and benefit systems were largely separate entities such that differential uprating is fairly easy to justify and implement. Over the 1990s and particularly since the election of the Labour government in 1997, the tax and benefit systems have become much more closely aligned, with many 'benefits', such as the various tax credits, being administered by the Inland Revenue. Thus it may be that the further we wish to take this analysis, the less straightforward it would be to have separate uprating factors for taxes and benefits. It should be noted, though, that in some cases, these new benefits are explicitly income-linked — the child tax credit has been linked to earnings for the lifetime of the second Labour Parliament, for example, and the pension credit is also earnings-linked. Of course, the further from the repeal of the earnings ratchet the analysis begins, the harder it is to use historical justification for an earnings uprating index for benefits — the legislation itself created a new historical precedent for price- uprating. This is why studies such as Brewer et al. (2004), which looked at reforms from 1997 only, did not consider this counterfactual.

This follows the earlier results in Table 3, where including indirect taxes raised the inequality-promoting effects of reforms and including employer NICs reduced them by around 1 percentage point. The results for all years including indirect taxes and employer NICs are not reported here but are available from the authors.

We do not look at changes to employer National Insurance in this simulation. Since this raised significant amounts of revenue, were we to include it the fiscal effects of the reforms would be to improve the government finances substantially relative to the 'do-nothing' counterfactuals. Indirect tax reforms are, however, included.

This is the 'constant progressivity' counterfactual we discussed earlier. Using this counterfactual, the effects of reforms to the tax and benefit system have been to increase inequality as measured by the Gini by 4 percentage points. This is a similar result to that under our historical counterfactual where benefits were increased by nominal GDP but tax thresholds by prices. However, the overall effect of the reforms under the constant progressivity counterfactual turns out to be slightly lower. This is because if tax thresholds had increased with nominal GDP, fiscal drag would not have happened, meaning that there would be fewer people paying tax and fewer higher-rate taxpayers. This reduces the amount of redistribution being done relative to price-indexing of tax thresholds.

0f course, one can argue that governments over time have different aims with regard to overall levels of taxation and spending and the 'size' of government. Our results suggest that relative to full price-indexation, tax and benefit reforms have made the government significantly worse off. This does not mean that price- indexation is not a credible counterfactual, since this loss comes mainly from large cuts in tax rates which were probably implemented with the aim of making the government sector smaller.

The effect on inequality of tax and benefit reforms compared with this counterfactual is to increase it by 3 percentage points. This constant uprating factor was also applied to duties — see footnote 14.
